displayed_text: Patient: Right. So I get twelve and twelve; I’ll take it at twelve and then I’ll take it again at twelve midnight. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: When I’m laying down and going to sleep. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And this is… Doctor: This is the sleeping pill, the Restoril. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright and these are your blood tests which you take over. Your calcium is good now so you can get… Patient: My calcium is good and I don’t have to take the big bills? Doctor: So it sounds like the big pills, you’re doing what I told you to. Doctor: Oh God.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So that, that is also in the back of my mind. And, because, because then I feel like we might have actually harmed you by missing the opportunity to give, you know, an FDA-approved therapy. Of course, that would be through K___ because that would be standard therapy. Um, so that’s what the other part of my thinking. Patient: Okay. And, and from my perspective, I didn’t believe that this was going to be easy from the, from the beginning. I remember when I came, I came to J___ H___ for a reason. I came here for a consultation because I wasn’t comfortable, uh, with the options that I believe K___ was offering. I came initially for that reason. It’s strange that it was my dentist, so we talk about a lot. It’s strange how you get into certain things, uh, by having relationships with people who have gone through it. My dentist had, uh, numerous family members, had dealt with cancer, and he had recommended, he said, you know what, D___, this is what you need to do. You need to go to one of the teaching hospitals either here in DC you can go to J___ H___, in B___, and from my perspective, there are enough individuals that have come to J___ H___, that are close friends of mine. Doctor: Okay. Patient: That said, they shared with me that, uh, if you have a choice, go to J___ H___. So when I came up, my thing was the consultation. We had the consultation. I left, and, uh, and I didn’t say anything. But there was a follow-up that was set for J___ H___. And we sat down, and we talked about this. So we have all these options here. We did the genetic testing. And I said, okay, this is an option just like anything else. If it does not work, it’s not like it’s the only option that we have. Doctor: Correct. Patient: If it does not work. But, at the same time, I think you have to give the, uh, the drug the opportunity – to work. Doctor: Right. Patient: And that’s why initially when we started, and, uh, and L___, she said, well, Mr. S___, you have the clinical trial. And I believe we’ve, we’ve had, we took the clinical trial. I knew that the doses that I was going to have was, was in a low dosage, and I know it’s going to have some effect there. So my thing is, D___, deal with it as long as you can. So I did. We lowered it down. I have felt changes. I used to have pain, uh, running down this area. I mean serious pain. My back, wherever I used to have pain here, and, uh, I don’t have it anymore. Now, yes, she does rub me down every night. I take two hot, uh, uh, baths each day. Sometimes in the morning, sometimes at night. Uh, I take those hot baths because when I stiffen up or, and, uh, I kind of said, okay, I need to get in the tub. I put some Epsom salt sitting in, and I sit in the tub about fifteen minutes, and then I get back out. And I said, okay, I can deal with another day. So, again, from my perspective, is that I wanted to see the drug do what it needs to do. I don’t know what the window is. I’m not a medical professional, whatever, so I don’t know that. But I do know that I have seen, uh, uh, changes taking place. I do know that even now I could go and walk around this block. Uh, I shouldn’t, but I probably could. So, uh, the sleeping part, the OxyContin sometimes works, uh, when I take it and I go to sleep. But during the daytime while you’re at work, I normally, I can’t do what I used to do, but I can get along pretty good. We’re talking about at night. We’re talking about at night. And I’m trying to get comfortable in the bed. I wish I could sleep on my stomach but I haven’t figured out a way of, uh, sleeping back on my stomach like I used to. Uh, I just don’t feel comfortable when I sleep on my stomach. So, I’m not, uh, disagreeing with what you said your observations are, uh, but, I’m trying to work with the, with the prescription that we’re taking already. And I didn’t think it was going to be easy. If it was going to be easy, uh, this drug probably would have been FDA approved a long time ago, if it was going to be easy. You know? It may not work. But, again, you never know. We were off of it for, uh, I think three weeks. Family Member: Three weeks. Patient: Three weeks. And then I got a call from two doctors. I don’t even remember where their office is. And they said that, uh, my cancer had stabilized. Doctor: Um hum.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: that’s it. Just one time. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um and it’s proven to help improve for you to live longer. Patient: Right. Doctor: For folks just like you. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. It comes with side effects because it’s never nothing without nothing. Patient: What is the side effects? Doctor: Number one, two and three is tiredness. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And tiredness isn’t that your brain isn’t functioning, functioning great. Patient: Just physically tired?

Patient: Until the third of January or something. Doctor: You could wait until the third of January, or you could -- Patient: Now, if you got - You, you – I grabbed that number out of the air. You can – Doctor: You could try to wait or things like that. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, he could wait. Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Because, again, I like to wait a little bit. Patient: After the, uh, hormones? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have some data that says says, um, people tolerate the chemo better once, uh, they have a little bit more space between getting the hormones and the chemo together. So Patient: Okay. Doctor: Let your body’s level of testosterone drop. Then, get the chemo, uh - that may be safer on your bone marrow than doing it all at once. Patient: That’s a done deal.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then a third group that doesn’t respond at all. Uh, so that would be the easiest thing. That’s a, you know, that’s the prescription. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That, that’s choice one. Choice two would be to give you chemotherapy at this point. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, I think, for me, what I would prefer is to try another hormone pill before we do chemotherapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Particularly because you’re not really symptomatic right now, I don’t think, and, you know, the, the benefits of both, uh, are about the same. Uh, so, and the side effects of chemotherapy are just, you know-? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: More to deal with. So, so if we were going to choose, uh, I would probably choose one of the hormone pills as the next thing to do. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, the clinical trials that we have, uh, at this point, uh, whether you’re ready to do another clinical trial after having just been on one. (Laughter) Doctor: Uh, the one upside of clinical trials is, you might of noticed, is you get a research nurse who kind of is like your concierge who runs everything for you.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.::: strongly disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Family Member: Oh, I see. Doctor: I think that’s a little more unusual gene. So. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So, whether that’s what it is -- Family Member: It affected pregnancy. So, that’s why it was in our family, but also Doctor: Did they test her children or anything or? Family Member: Uh, no she doesn’t have children. Patient: She doesn’t have children. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: She couldn’t. That’s part of the issue. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: It’s a blood thing, too. So, um. Doctor: It’s, it’s a gene that affects the body’s ability to use folate. (Pause)

Patient: Today, you know, I mean -- I didn’t know what I have or what I don’t have. I’ve got no pain. I don’t have you know, what did we talk about before? So, then, it’s not a twenty year old’s dream anymore but, um, I would, I would say I probably have waken up a little bit more often which, my sleep patterns really disturbed even from my normal pattern. In that, um, I’m up at two o’clock in the morning and go to the bathroom and then go to sleep until anywhere from (between six and eight.) Doctor: Uh, so you get up and you just can’t get back to sleep? Or, you got something on your mind? Patient: Um. hhh It is, it is mostly just a little bit of, just the wheels won’t stop. Doctor: So, cancer stuff or work stuff? Or at home? Patient: D, all the above. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: When we were talkin’ about, we were talkin’ about trials? And only some of the trials are medical. So. Doctor: And so, if you don’t get back to sleep in the morning, uh, you fall asleep during the day or? Patient: I’ll take a nap. Maybe an hour’s worth. And then, drive on for the day. From, about three or, three or four - Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Is really the low end. Doctor: And, do you think you’re depressed or?

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know that’s an early phase—Phase I study. That clearly has no data as to whether it works. And so you could window it in at this point, but if the scans when we get them show that the stuff that’s in your liver is even big in other areas, Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you know whether or not you have the willingness or sort of the time to sort of participate in something that’s you know experimental of that nature of a brand new drug is questionable. But some people clearly want to avoid chemotherapy at all costs and are willing to try that even if you know it doesn’t work and they were to miss that opportunity for chemotherapy. So everybody sort of chooses based on who they talk to, who their neighbors are, who’s been through chemo. Doctor: What they are willing to think about. Patient: Yes, I have the time. Yeah. Doctor: Time is one thing, but again you know what the cancer is going to do is the other. Patient: Side effects and all that, yeah, I don’t know what, yeah. Doctor: So those would be potentially three options. If we’re going to go chemotherapy, whether we add in the Vitamin C or not; you get the infusion, you don’t know whether it’s the real thing or Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you get the real chemo. The other one is the immune therapy which my reservation at this point is the gasping thing. Family Member: Mm, hmm.

Patient: Good. You remember my daughter, E_______? Doctor: Yes, of course! Family Member: Hi. Doctor: She was your-- Family Member: Nice to see you! Doctor: Lucky charm. Patient: You're right. Doctor: Okay, we have a medical student. I think they told you that he will be in. Did she tell you that? Patient: Yeah. That's right, yeah. That's right. Doctor: Um, okay, that um... Patient: That's fine. Patient: Good. The drops have been helping. Doctor: The redness is all gone. How about the tearing? Even that is better?

Patient: Right. Doctor: But given that you don’t have anything else visible and all these years you haven’t had anything evolve. Patient: Right. Doctor: And this is the only area, I am thinking it’s worthwhile considering the cryo procedure. Okay? Patient: The whole thing or is this a partial? Doctor: Well no I think almost all of the prostate will need to be cryoed. So that’s why I figure Dr. C____ should come in and talk to you. Explain the details of the procedure and he’s saying that urinary leakage and everything chances are about one in four after the procedure, but that’s the risk we take and remember we talked about that that you know do we want to take that leakage risk. But given what I’m seeing is it’s that or wait until the prostate gland blocks your urinary flow which is not a good outcome at all. Right, yeah. If that wasn’t such an immediate threat, then I would have said no just sit tight, don’t do anything. Patient: Right. Doctor: But because of that threat I’m tempted to say maybe we should get it in control while we can rather than waiting until that bad outcome happens. Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So that’s why I’ll have Dr. C____ come in first, explain the procedure, what it involves, what the risks are, all of that – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - and then I’ll just touch base with you after he’s spoken to. Okay? Patient: Yeah.

Patient: I – yeah. Whatever. Doctor: I got a great idea! Patient: What? Doctor: Let’s do this! Family Member: I gotta get out. Doctor: Right. (Laughs) Patient: What? Doctor: Let’s get M__ to just talk hard, here’s what gotta do, thinkin’ movin’ forward. Patient: Who is M_? Doctor: M_ S_!!!! You know M_! She’s the research nurse! You’ve talked to her a thousand times already! Patient: Ohhhh. Family Member: She come back every day.

Patient: Uh, you know, I am, uh, there, there was a few times whereas I felt like, uh, some pressure up here, and I just felt very lethargic, and, um, I took some, um, some aspirin- Doctor: Okay. Patient: Uh, or Tylenol, and that seemed to, you know, put me back in a normal state. Doctor: How are you doing just overall, just the anxiety, and sort of in the past you had some issues with that. Does that kind of seem like it’s controlled or-? Patient: Uh, yeah. Yeah. That’s, that’s more controlled. I think, you know, since, since I’ve been retired, I haven’t really had, other than flare-ups sometimes with my son, but for the most part, uh, you know, I’m pretty, you know, level minded. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Any new pain anywhere? Patient: No uh. Well, every once in a while, I get like a stiffness in my thighs. Doctor: Okay. When you’re doing something or just anytime? Patient: Every once in a while. Uh, it just, it just pops up. Doctor: And it’s in both thighs or one or-? Patient: Uh, sometimes it’s in both. Normally, it’s in both.

Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And for reasons that are complicated related to business and how, you know, how these things happen. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So far, until recently, this hasn’t been in the right hands, I think, to make a drug out of it. Recently, there’s been a lot of interest and a very large company bought the rights to it, and I think they’re going to do it correctly. But it’s been a slow moving thing to get started. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And, and some of the complexity relates to, to, uh, how the drug’s supplied. Anyway, so that, that is a radioactive thing that’s coming. The radium, we could do that as just a standard treatment, not even part of a trial. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I must say that outside of a trial, I haven’t been that excited about the radium, to be honest, in the patients I’ve treated. Family Member: Why? Doctor: Uh, it’s been kind of toxic to the bone marrow. People have kind of gotten beat up when they take it and feeling really tired. Um, and in the trials where it got approved, uh, it didn’t really have big effects on the PSA. It didn’t have big effects on shrink, you know, changing the bone. The only readout was the people who got it seemed to live long. (Sound Door closes) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I think, you know, we- Patient: Is that how it works when they give, give the, uh, the seeds in the prostate? Is that, is that similar to that process?

Patient: No. Um, none at this time. Doctor: Okay. So, what we’ll do is we’ll um we’ll be able to answer some questions over the phone when we call you as well in about a week. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Talk to you about the clinical trials. If you read through this and you say thanks but no thanks, that’s perfectly fine. I’m still going to be your doc and I’m still going to be your oncologist. Um and you have every right you know to turn this down if it’s not right for you. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But this a reasonable option that um if I was the patient, I would also consider. So I will leave that with you, put that underneath this one. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And then uh we will get back in touch with you either later this week- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Or early next week. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: And uh-

Patient: Doc, Doc, Doc, that’s another thing. Doctor: What? Patient: I ain’t going to the bathroom regularly and started taking my stool softeners and then I’m mixing up the what-ya-call-it too. Doctor: Yep, that’s what you gotta do. You want me to put this here? I just gave him the side effect sheet. Patient: I need. Family Member: I was gonna look them up anyway. Patient: Let me say this here, Doc. Let me say this here. Everything that you tell me and you do – Doctor: Mm,hmm. Patient: she goes and she looks up everything Doctor: Perfect. Yes. Patient: You know I’m just surrounded with just good people taking good care. Doctor: People who care. Here’s what I said about the bike trip. It’s up to him really to be smart about it. You know I know he loves it and this is something he just has to work out by himself and also with you guys. There’s no real medical reason technically and it’s gonna take us a week or two to get that medicine, so there’s time. He says he’s not gonna stay down in F____.
